====United States==== {{main|Age discrimination in the United States}} In the United States, each [[List of states and territories of the United States|state]] has its own laws regarding age discrimination, and there are also federal laws.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/international/Pages/USA.aspx USA]. Agediscrimination.info. Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> In California, the [[California Fair Employment and Housing Act of 1959|Fair Employment and Housing Act]] forbids unlawful discrimination against persons age 40 and older. The FEHA is the principal California statute prohibiting employment discrimination, covering employers, labor organizations, employment agencies, apprenticeship programs and/or any person or entity who aids, abets, incites, compels, or coerces the doing of a discriminatory act. In addition to age, it prohibits employment discrimination based on race or color; religion; national origin or ancestry, [[disability]], mental type or medical condition; marital status; sex or sexual orientation; and pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions.<ref>[http://finduslaw.com/california_fair_employment_and_housing_act_feha_government_code_12900_12996 California Fair Employment and Housing Act] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070114000317/http://finduslaw.com/california_fair_employment_and_housing_act_feha_government_code_12900_12996 |date=14 January 2007 }} FindLaw.</ref> Although there are many protections for age-based discrimination against older workers (as shown above), there are less protections for younger workers.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
The [[District of Columbia]] and twelve states (California, Florida, [[Iowa]], Hawaii, [[Kansas]], [[Louisiana]], [[Maine]], [[Minnesota]], [[Nebraska]], [[New Mexico]], New York, and [[Vermont]]) define age as a specific motivation for hate crimes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anti-Defamation League State Hate Crime Statutory Provisions (2005)|url=http://www.adl.org/learn/hate_crimes_laws/State_Hate_Crime_Statutory_Provisions_chart.pdf|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629085842/http://www.adl.org/learn/hate_crimes_laws/State_Hate_Crime_Statutory_Provisions_chart.pdf|archive-date=29 June 2011|access-date=22 May 2009}} {{small|(23.8 KB)}} (See page 1, section "Other", note 2) Retrieved on 21 May 2009</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Everyday Fears – A Survey of Violent Hate Crimes in Europe and North America|url=http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/discrimination/pdf/everyday-fears-080805.pdf|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060112034643/http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/discrimination/pdf/everyday-fears-080805.pdf|archive-date=12 January 2006|access-date=22 May 2009}} {{small|(1.96 MB)}} McClintock, Michael (See pages 84 and 122, Appendix 10, "Others", note 2) Retrieved on 21 May 2009</ref>
The federal government restricts age discrimination under the [[Age Discrimination in Employment Act]] of 1967 (ADEA). That law provides certain employment protections to workers who are over the age of 40, who work for an employer who has twenty or more employees. For protected workers, the ADEA prohibits discrimination at all levels of employment, from recruitment and hiring, through the employment relationship, and through decisions for layoffs or termination of the employment relationship. An age limit may only be legally specified for protected workers in the circumstance where age has been shown to be a "[[bona fide occupational qualification]] [BFOQ] reasonably necessary to the normal operation of the particular business" (see {{usc|29|623(f)(1)}}). In practice, BFOQs for age are limited to the obvious (hiring a young actor to play a young character in a movie) or when public safety is at stake (for example, in the case of age limits for pilots and bus drivers). The ADEA does not stop an employer from favoring an older employee over a younger one, even when the younger one is over 40 years old.<ref name="auto2" /> [[File:Jimmy Carter participates in a bill signing ceremony - NARA - 178763.tif|thumb|President [[Jimmy Carter]] signing legislation against mandatory retirement in 1978]] [[Mandatory retirement]] due to age is generally unlawful in the United States, except in certain industries and occupations that are regulated by law, and are often part of the government (such as military service and federal police agencies, such as the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]). [[Minnesota]] has statutorily established mandatory retirement for all judges at age 70 (more precisely, at the end of the month a judge reaches that age). The [[Minnesota Legislature]] has had the constitutional right to set judicial retirement ages since 1956, but did not do so until 1973, setting the age at 70.<ref name="auto">{{cite news|last=Stassen-Berger|first=Rachel E.|date=7 July 2015|title=Minnesota judges aren't making a fuss about retirement rule|newspaper=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press|Pioneer Press]]|location=[[Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul, MN]]|url=http://www.twincities.com/politics/ci_28448632/rachel-stassen-berger-minnesota-judges-arent-making-fuss|access-date=28 December 2015|archive-date=9 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160109015539/http://www.twincities.com/politics/ci_28448632/rachel-stassen-berger-minnesota-judges-arent-making-fuss|url-status=live}}</ref> In 1978 President [[Jimmy Carter]] signed a law banning employers from requiring most employees to retire because of age before age 70 and ending mandatory retirement for most federal employees.<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1978/04/07/new-law-sets-70-retirement-age/067d7314-7c60-445c-8cd2-57e59428b20e/</ref> The Federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act, which became law in 1986, ended mandatory age-related retirement at age 70 for many jobs, not including the Minnesota judiciary;<ref name="auto" /> another exception was all postsecondary institutions (colleges, etc.) This exception ended on 31 December 1993.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Weinberg|first1=Sharon L.|last2=Scott|first2=Marc A.|year=2013|title=The Impact of Uncapping of Mandatory Retirement on Postsecondary Institutions|url=https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.3102/0013189X13497993|journal=Educational Researcher|volume=42|issue=6|pages=338–348|doi=10.3102/0013189X13497993|s2cid=13265704}}</ref><ref>Sanjek, Roger (2009). Gray Panthers. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 185.</ref> The Fair Treatment for Experienced Pilots Act (Public Law 110–135) went into effect on 13 December 2007, raising the mandatory retirement age for pilots to 65 from the previous 60.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.faa.gov/news/press_releases/news_story.cfm?newsId=10072|title=FAA Statement on Pilot Retirement Age|date=14 December 2007|access-date=21 October 2012|archive-date=25 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025142224/http://www.faa.gov/news/press_releases/news_story.cfm?newsId=10072|url-status=live}}</ref> Air traffic controllers have a mandatory retirement age of 56, with exceptions up to age 61. Most air traffic controllers are hired before the age of 31 (the hiring cutoff age for those with experience is 36).<ref>{{cite web | url=https://uscode.house.gov/view.xhtml?req=granuleid:USC-prelim-title5-section8335&num=0&edition=prelim | title=5 USC 8335: Mandatory separation }}</ref> Foreign Service employees at the Department of State have a mandatory retirement age of 65 with very narrow exceptions. Federal law enforcement officers, national park rangers and firefighters have a mandatory retirement age of 57, or later if they have had less than 20 years of service.<ref>[http://www.cpms.osd.mil/ASSETS/3F5D404B9512488C8E4D8DE9213A485D/Special_Retirement_Ref_Guide31Jan2011.pdf SPECIAL RETIREMENT PROVISIONS FOR LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS, FIREFIGHTERS AND AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLERS] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120925042738/http://www.cpms.osd.mil/ASSETS/3F5D404B9512488C8E4D8DE9213A485D/Special_Retirement_Ref_Guide31Jan2011.pdf |date=25 September 2012 }}, Defense Civilian Personnel Management Service, January 2011</ref> For [[Florida Supreme Court]] justices, the Florida Constitution establishes mandatory retirement at age 70. [[Judiciary of Michigan|Michigan judges]] of all levels cannot run for election after passing the age of 70. In the [[New Hampshire Constitution]], Article 78 sets the retirement of all judges and sheriffs at age 70. The [[New Jersey Supreme Court]] has established mandatory retirement at age 70. The [[Maryland Constitution]] establishes a mandatory retirement age of 70 for Circuit and Appellate Court judges. [[Oregon]] has a mandatory judicial retirement age of 75.
{{main article|Age of candidacy laws in the United States}} In the United States, a person must be aged 35 or over to serve as president. To be a senator, a person must be aged 30 or over. To be a Representative, a person must be aged 25 or older. This is specified in the [[Article Two of the United States Constitution#Clause 5: Qualifications for office|U.S. Constitution]]. Most states in the U.S. also have age requirements for the offices of Governor, State Senator, and State Representative.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://definitions.uslegal.com/a/age-of-candidacy/|title=Age of Candidacy Law & Legal Definition|publisher=USLegal.com |access-date=7 November 2012}}</ref> Some states have a minimum age requirement to hold any elected office (usually 21 or 18).
In September 2016, California passed state bill AB-1687, an anti-ageism law taking effect on 1 January 2017, requiring "commercial online entertainment employment" services that allow paid subscribers to submit information and resumes (such as [[IMDbPro]]), to honor requests to have their ages and birthdays removed. The bill was supported by [[SAG-AFTRA]]'s former and current presidents [[Ken Howard]] and [[Gabrielle Carteris]], who felt that the law would help to reduce ageism in the entertainment industry.<ref name="thr-imdblaw">{{cite web|title=California Enacts Law Requiring IMDb to Remove Actor Ages on Request|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/california-enacts-law-requiring-imdb-932330|access-date=15 November 2016|website=The Hollywood Reporter|date=24 September 2016|archive-date=28 November 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201128211852/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/california-enacts-law-requiring-imdb-932330|url-status=live}}</ref> On 23 February 2017, U.S. District Judge Vince Girdhari Chhabria issued a stay on the bill pending a further trial, claiming that it was "difficult to imagine how AB 1687 could not violate the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]]" because it inhibited the public consumption of factual information.<ref name="thr-lawstruck">{{cite web|title=Judge Pauses Enforcement of IMDb Age Censorship Law|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/judge-pauses-enforcement-imdb-age-censorship-law-978797|access-date=23 February 2017|website=The Hollywood Reporter|date=22 February 2017|archive-date=12 November 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201112020222/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/judge-pauses-enforcement-imdb-age-censorship-law-978797|url-status=live}}</ref> In February 2018, Girdhari ruled that the law was unconstitutional, arguing that the state of California "[had] not shown that partially eliminating one source of age-related information will appreciably diminish the amount of age discrimination occurring in the entertainment industry." The ruling was criticized by SAG-AFTRA, alleging that the court "incorrectly concluded there were no material disputed factual issues, while precluding the parties from acquiring additional evidence or permitting the case to go to trial". The ruling was eventually appealed, but the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld it in 2020.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Pedersen|first=Erik|date=20 February 2018|title=California's IMDb Age Law Violates First Amendment, Federal Court Rules; SAG-AFTRA "Extremely Disappointed" – Update|language=en-US|work=Deadline|url=https://deadline.com/2020/06/imdb-age-law-violates-first-amendment-california-1202296413/|access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref>
====Venezuela==== In [[Venezuela]], a person must be at least 30 to be [[President of Venezuela|President]] or [[Vice President of Venezuela|Vice President]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.psuv.org.ve/constitucion/titulo5-capitulo2/|title=Capítulo II | PSUV}}</ref> 21 to be a deputy for the [[National Assembly of Venezuela|National Assembly]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.psuv.org.ve/constitucion/titulo5-capitulo1/|title=Capítulo I | PSUV}}</ref> and 25 to be the Governor of a [[States of Venezuela|state]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.psuv.org.ve/constitucion/titulo4-capitulo3/|title=Capítulo III | PSUV}}</ref>
===Asia and Oceania=== ====Australia==== In regards to employment, discrimination on the basis of age is illegal in each of the states and territories of Australia. At the national level, Australia is party to a number of international treaties and conventions that impose obligations to eliminate age discrimination.<ref name="bfr1">{{cite book |last1=Bittman |first1=Michael |url=http://www.jamesmahmudrice.info/SPRCR601.pdf |title=The Recruitment of Older Australian Workers: A Survey of Employers in a High Growth Industry |last2=Flick |first2=Mardi |last3=Rice |first3=James |publisher=Social Policy Research Centre, [[University of New South Wales]] |year=2001 |isbn=978-0-7334-1908-9 |location=Sydney, NSW |pages=14–15 |access-date=30 June 2013 |archive-date=9 April 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110409063552/http://www.jamesmahmudrice.info/SPRCR601.pdf |url-status=live }}</ref> The Australian Human Rights Commission Act 1986 established the [[Australian Human Rights Commission]] and bestows on this Commission functions in relation to a number of international treaties and conventions that cover age discrimination.<ref name="bfr1" /><ref name="ahrc">{{cite web |title = Legislation | Australian Human Rights Commission |url = https://www.humanrights.gov.au/our-work/legal/legislation |access-date = 27 April 2013 |publisher = [[Australian Human Rights Commission]] |archive-date = 26 April 2013 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130426002407/http://www.humanrights.gov.au/our-work/legal/legislation |url-status = live }}</ref> During 1998–1999, 15% of complaints received by the Commission under the Act were about discrimination on the basis of age.<ref name="bfr1" />
Age discrimination laws at the national level were strengthened by the [[Age Discrimination Act 2004]], which helps to ensure that people are not subjected to age discrimination in various areas of public life, including employment, the provision of goods and services, education, and the administration of Australian government laws and programs. The Act, however, does provide for exemptions in some areas, as well as providing for positive discrimination, that is, actions which assist people of a particular age who experience a disadvantage because of their age.<ref name="ahrc" /> In 2011, the position of Age Discrimination Commissioner was created within the Australian Human Rights Commission. The Commissioner's responsibilities include raising awareness among employers about the beneficial contributions that senior Australians as well as younger employees can make in the workforce.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=431 In Australia, new age discrimination laws have been passed by the Federal Parliament; a position of Age Discrimination Commissioner has been created in the Australian Human Rights Commission for the first time] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110916060514/http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=431 |date=16 September 2011 }}. Agediscrimination.info (26 May 2011). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> Every state in Australia has a probationary plate system for driver which is a known exemption to the Age Discrimination Act which allows different treatment in certain circumstances.<ref>[https://www.humanrights.gov.au/know-your-rights-age-discrimination When is age discrimination not against the law?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170307123650/https://www.humanrights.gov.au/know-your-rights-age-discrimination |date=7 March 2017 }} humanrights.gov.au Retrieved 7 March 2017</ref> Another exception is running for office; in [[Australia]] a person must be aged 18 or over to stand for election to public office at federal, state or local government level. The [[Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918|Electoral Act 1918]] was amended (in 1973) to reduce the [[age of candidacy]] for the [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] from 21 to 18.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Departments/Parliamentary_Library/pubs/rp/rp1314/43rdParl|title=The 43rd Parliament: traits and trends|last=Lumb|first=Martin|date=2 October 2013 |website=Parliament of Australia |language=en-AU|access-date=28 December 2019}}</ref>
Compulsory retirement is generally unlawful throughout the various State and Territory jurisdictions in Australia.<ref>{{cite web |title=Age discrimination |url=https://www.humanrights.gov.au/our-work/employers/age-discrimination |website=Australian Human Rights Commission |access-date=26 April 2020 |date=18 February 2015}}</ref> Among exceptions to the general rule, permanent members of the [[Australian Defence Force]] must retire at the age of 60 and reservists at 65.<ref name="ALRC">{{cite web|last1=Australian Law Reform Commission|title=Recruitment and Employment Law|url=http://www.alrc.gov.au/publications/2-recruitment-and-employment-law/compulsory-retirement|website=Grey Areas—Age Barriers to Work in Commonwealth Laws (DP 78)|publisher=Australian Law Reform Commission|access-date=31 December 2016|date=2012|archive-date=31 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161231170721/http://www.alrc.gov.au/publications/2-recruitment-and-employment-law/compulsory-retirement|url-status=dead}}</ref> As well, since the passage of [[Australian referendum, 1977 (Retirement of Judges)|a constitutional amendment]] in 1977, judges on [[Australian court hierarchy|federal courts]] are required to retire at the age of 70.<ref name="ALRC" />
The [[Australian Human Rights Commission]] has conducted a number of research projects on ageism including What's Age Got to do with it in 2021, Employing and retaining older workers in 2021 and the Willing to Work: Healthy Ageing Paper in 2016.<ref>{{cite web |title=Publications |url=https://humanrights.gov.au/our-work/age-discrimination/publications |website=Australian Human Rights Commission |access-date=14 July 2024 |archive-date=10 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240410123620/https://humanrights.gov.au/our-work/age-discrimination/publications |url-status=live }}</ref> Other active organizations include EveryAge Counts and the [[Council on the Ageing]].

===Europe=== ====European Union==== [[European Union|European]] citizenship provides the right to protection from discrimination on the grounds of age. According to Article 21–1 of the [[Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union|Charter of Fundamental Rights]] of the [[European Union]] [[s:Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union#CHAPTER III. EQUALITY]], "any discrimination based on any ground such as{{Nbsp}}… age, shall be prohibited".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.europarl.europa.eu/charter/pdf/text_en.pdf |title= Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (official text) |access-date= 9 May 2009 |archive-date= 29 May 2010 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100529042731/http://www.europarl.europa.eu/charter/pdf/text_en.pdf |url-status= live }} {{small|(80.6 KB)}}</ref>
Additional protection against age discrimination comes from the Framework Directive 2000/78/EC. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of age in the field of employment.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/legislation/Pages/ECLegislation.aspx EC Legislation] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721184455/http://www.agediscrimination.info/legislation/Pages/ECLegislation.aspx |date=21 July 2011 }}. Agediscrimination.info. Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
''[[Mangold v Helm]]'' (2005) [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:62004CJ0144&from=EN C-144/04] was a case before the [[European Court of Justice]] (ECJ) about age discrimination in employment.<ref name="auto4">E McGaughey, ''A Casebook on Labour Law'' (Hart 2019) ch 15, 657</ref> Mangold was a 56-year-old German man employed on a fixed term contract in a permanent [[full-time job]]. The German government introduced the so-called Employment Promotion Act 1996 ({{langx|de|Beschäftigungsförderungsgesetz}}) which allowed fixed term contracts for a two-year maximum, and otherwise were unlawful unless they could be objectively justified. But even this protection was removed (apparently to "promote employment") if the employee was over 60. Further amendments then changed the age to 52. Mr. Mangold claimed that the lack of protection, over age 52, was unjustified age discrimination. The ECJ held in its judgment the German law contravened the [[Employment Equality Framework Directive]], even though it did not have to be implemented until the end of 2006. It said that, in general terms, legislation that lets employers treat people differently because of their age “offends the principle” in international law of eliminating discrimination on the basis of age. {{Citation needed|reason=Every citation must be justified by a verified source|date=March 2024}} The ECJ ruled that national courts must set aside any provision of national law which conflicts with the directive even before the period for implementation has expired.
''[[Kücükdeveci v Swedex GmbH & Co KG]]'' (2010) {{CELEX|62007J0555|text=C-555/07}} is a leading [[EU labour law]] case, which held that there is a [[General principles of European Union law|general principle of law]] in all European Union member states, against discrimination, and in favour of equal treatment.<ref name="auto1">E McGaughey, ''A Casebook on Labour Law'' (Hart 2019) ch 12, 534</ref> The case concerned Ms. Kücükdeveci, who argued that the German service related statutory minimum notice period, because it disregarded employment before the age of 25, was unjustifiably discriminatory against young people. The European Court of Justice (Grand Chamber) held that the legislation was contrary to the [[Employment Equality Framework Directive]] 2000/78/EC, but also following ''[[Mangold v Helm]]'' a general principle of equality which permeates all of EU law, to which the Directive merely gave expression. This is more so because the Charter of Fundamental Rights article 21(1) says the same and that has the same legal value as the treaties under TEU art 6(1). Accordingly, in paragraphs [23]-[31], it was held that the legislation in BGB §622 was discriminatory. There was not a sufficient objective justification for the measure, because although the German government's professed aim of wishing to bolster youth employment was legitimate, its measure was disproportionate. In paragraphs [44]-[56] the ECJ further held that national courts have a duty to disapply any provision of national legislation contrary to the principle of equal treatment. They should not be compelled to make a reference to the ECJ first. One should note that the EU law can only be applied when there is a cross-border issue.<ref name="auto3">{{Cite web |title=Case C-555/07 |url=https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:62007CJ0555&from=GA }}</ref>

''[[Mangold v Helm]]'' (2005) [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:62004CJ0144&from=EN C-144/04] was a case before the [[European Court of Justice]] (ECJ) about age discrimination in employment.<ref name="auto4"/> Mangold was a 56-year-old German man employed on a fixed term contract in a permanent [[full-time job]]. The German government introduced the so-called Employment Promotion Act 1996 ({{langx|de|Beschäftigungsförderungsgesetz}}) which allowed fixed term contracts for a two-year maximum, and otherwise were unlawful unless they could be objectively justified. But even this protection was removed (apparently to "promote employment") if the employee was over 60. Further amendments then changed the age to 52. Mr. Mangold claimed that the lack of protection, over age 52, was unjustified age discrimination. The ECJ held in its judgment the German law contravened the [[Employment Equality Framework Directive]], even though it did not have to be implemented until the end of 2006. It said that, in general terms, legislation that lets employers treat people differently because of their age “offends the principle” in international law of eliminating discrimination on the basis of age. {{Citation needed|reason=Every citation must be justified by a verified source|date=March 2024}} The ECJ ruled that national courts must set aside any provision of national law which conflicts with the directive even before the period for implementation has expired.
''[[Kücükdeveci v Swedex GmbH & Co KG]]'' (2010) {{CELEX|62007J0555|text=C-555/07}} is a leading [[EU labour law]] case, which held that there is a [[General principles of European Union law|general principle of law]] in all European Union member states, against discrimination, and in favour of equal treatment.<ref name="auto1"/> The case concerned Ms. Kücükdeveci, who argued that the German service related statutory minimum notice period, because it disregarded employment before the age of 25, was unjustifiably discriminatory against young people. The European Court of Justice (Grand Chamber) held that the legislation was contrary to the [[Employment Equality Framework Directive]] 2000/78/EC, but also following ''[[Mangold v Helm]]'' a general principle of equality which permeates all of EU law, to which the Directive merely gave expression. This is more so because the Charter of Fundamental Rights article 21(1) says the same and that has the same legal value as the treaties under TEU art 6(1). Accordingly, in paragraphs [23]-[31], it was held that the legislation in BGB §622 was discriminatory. There was not a sufficient objective justification for the measure, because although the German government's professed aim of wishing to bolster youth employment was legitimate, its measure was disproportionate. In paragraphs [44]-[56] the ECJ further held that national courts have a duty to disapply any provision of national legislation contrary to the principle of equal treatment. They should not be compelled to make a reference to the ECJ first. One should note that the EU law can only be applied when there is a cross-border issue.<ref name="auto3"/>

In 2011, the artist Michael Freedman, an outspoken advocate against age discrimination within the art world, said that "I am really pissed off with the organisers of the majority of the competitions that seek artists to enter them. Many restrict entrants to those who are under 35! I have never seen a reason for this" and that "mature students, like me, come to art late in life, so why are we penalised and demotivated? Whatever happened to lifelong learning and the notion of a flexible workforce?"<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.michaelfreedman.co.uk/2011/12/ageism-in-the-art-world/|first = Michael|last = Freedman|title = Ageism in the Art World|date = 29 December 2011|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140508205817/http://www.michaelfreedman.co.uk/2011/12/ageism-in-the-art-world/|archive-date = 8 May 2014|access-date = 15 April 2019|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
===The Middle East===
====Iran==== In [[Iran]] a person must be at least 21 years old to run for president.<ref name=":Iran8">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/interactive/2013/06/2013611135620419515.html|title=Infographic: Choosing Iran's next president|last=Piven|first=Ben|author2=Ben Willers|date=11 June 2013|work=Al Jazeera English|access-date=12 June 2013}}</ref>
====Iraq==== The Iraqi constitution states that a person must be at least 40 years old to run for president<ref name="Iraq:9">Constitution of Iraq, Article 68</ref> and 35 years old to be prime minister.<ref name=":Iraq">Constitution of Iraq, Article 77</ref><ref name=":11">Iraqi Election Law 2019, Article 8(1)</ref> Until 2019, the electoral law set the age limit at 30 years old for candidates to run for the Council of Representatives.<ref>Law No. 45 of 2013 on Election of the Council of Representatives, Article 8 (a)</ref> However, the new Iraqi Council of Representatives Election Law (passed in 2019, yet to be enacted) lowered the age limit to 28.<ref>Law No.X of 2019 The Iraqi Council of Representatives Election Law, article 8(1)</ref>
====Israel==== A 2006 decision by Israel's High Court of Justice stated that mandatory retirement at age 67 does not discriminate against the elderly.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=MANDATORY RETIREMENT IS IT LEGAL?|author=Suri Epstein|magazine=[[binah (magazine)|Binah]]|date=5 February 2018|pages=25–26}}</ref>
In Israel one must be at least 21 to become a member of the [[Knesset]] ([[Basic Law: The Knesset]] section 6(a)) or a [[Municipal elections in Israel|municipality]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2021}} When the [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]] was directly elected, one must have been a member of the Knesset who is at least 30 to be a candidate for prime minister.{{Citation needed|date=December 2021}} Every Israeli Citizen (including minors) can be appointed as a [[Government of Israel|Government]] Minister, or elected as [[President of Israel]], but the latter role is mostly ceremonial and elected by the Parliament.{{Citation needed|date=December 2021}}
====Palestine==== Palestinian parliamentary candidates must be at least 28 years old, while the presidential candidates must be at least 40 years old.<ref>{{Cite web|title=General Election Laws|url=https://www.elections.ps/tabid/344/language/en-US/Default.aspx|access-date=2021-03-24|website=www.elections.ps}}</ref>
==Advocacy against ageism== [[File:Child Labor in United States 1910 working night shift.jpg|thumb|A 14-year-old newsboy in New York City, 1910]] The [[Newsboys Strike of 1899]] fought ageist employment practices targeted against the youth by large newspaper syndicates in the [[Northeastern United States|Northeast]] of America. The strikers demonstrated across the city for several days, effectively stopping circulation of the two papers, along with the news distribution for many [[New England]] cities. The [[Strike action|strike]] lasted two weeks, causing Pulitzer's ''[[New York World]]'' to decrease its circulation from 360,000 papers sold per day to 125,000.<ref>Nasaw, David. (1999) "Ch. 3: Youse an' yer noble scrap: On strike with the Newsboy Legion in 1899." in ''Big Town, Big Time.'' New York: New York Daily News. p. 9.</ref> Although the price of papers was not lowered, the strike was successful in forcing the ''World'' and ''Journal'' to offer full buybacks to their sellers, thus increasing the amount of money that newsies received for their work.<ref>Mott, F.L. (2000) ''American Journalism''. New York: Routledge. p. 598.</ref>
The [[American Youth Congress]], or AYC, was formed in 1935 to advocate for [[youth rights]] in U.S. politics. It ended in 1940.<ref>Black, A., Hopkins, J. ''et al.'' (2003) [http://www.nps.gov/archive/elro/glossary/american-youth-congress.htm "American Youth Congress,"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019032029/http://www.nps.gov/archive/elro/glossary/american-youth-congress.htm |date=19 October 2007 }} ''The Eleanor Roosevelt Papers.'' Teaching Eleanor Roosevelt. Hyde Park, New York: Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site. Retrieved 7/30/07.</ref> [[File:AARP Pride Booth Boston 2017.png|thumb|[[AARP]] booth at [[Boston]] Pride Festival, 2017]] [[AARP]] was founded in 1958 by [[Ethel Percy Andrus]] (a retired educator from California) and Leonard Davis (later the founder of the [[Colonial Penn Life Insurance Company|Colonial Penn Group]] of insurance companies).<ref>{{cite news|work=Los Angeles Times|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2001-jan-23-me-15772-story.html|date=23 January 2001|title=Local: Obituary|access-date=14 August 2024|archive-date=22 June news|url=https://news.usc.edu/6078/Obituary-AARP-founder-philanthropist-Leonard-Davis-76/|work=USC News|title=AARP Founder: Philanthropist Leonard Davis, 76|access-date=25 April 2020|archive-date=30 empower people to choose how they live as they age".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aarp.org/about-aarp/|title=About AARP|access-date=9 November 2018|archive-date=3 September 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230903231207/https://www.aarp.org/about-aarp/|url-status=live}}</ref> It is an influential [[lobbying]] group in the United States focusing largely on issues affecting the elderly.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thenonprofittimes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/8-1-15_Top50PI.pdf|title=The 2015 Power & Influence Top 50|date=31 August 2015|website=The NonProfit Times|access-date=25 April 2020|archive-date=17 September September 2016}}</ref>
[[Aid for the Elderly in Government Institutions]] (AEGIS) was a British [[pressure group]] that campaigned to improve the care of older people in long-stay wards of [[National Health Service]] [[psychiatric hospitals]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archives.lse.ac.uk/Record.aspx?src=CalmView.Catalog&id=AEGIS|title=AEGIS – AEGIS (Aid to the Elderly in Government Institutions)|website=LSE Library Services|access-date=16 May 2016|archive-date=26 September 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210926161816/https://archives.lse.ac.uk/Record.aspx?src=CalmView.Catalog&id=AEGIS|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Whitewash">{{Cite news|title=Whitewash in the old folks' wards|last=Robinson|first=Anne|date=5 April 1970|work=Sunday Times}}</ref> The group was founded by [[Barbara Robb]] in 1965,<ref name="Whitewash" /> and was active until her death in 1976.<ref>{{Cite news|title=The patients' campaigner|date=25 June 1976|work=Hampstead and Highgate Express}}</ref>
The [[Gray Panthers]] was formed in 1970 by [[Maggie Kuhn]], with a goal of eliminating [[mandatory retirement]] in the United States; they now work on many [[social justice]] issues including eliminating ageism.<ref>Kuhn, M., Long, C. and Quinn, L. (1991) ''No Stone Unturned: the Life and Times of Maggie Kuhn.'' Ballantine Books.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aarp.org/politics-society/history/champions-of-aging-photos/older-american-maggie-kuhn-gray-panthers.html|title=Maggie Kuhn – Champions of Aging|first=Patrick J.|last=Kiger|website=AARP|access-date=7 December 2020|archive-date=21 January 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210121220455/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/history/champions-of-aging-photos/older-american-maggie-kuhn-gray-panthers.html|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.graypanthersnyc.org/about_us/ |title=About Us |publisher=Gray Panthers Nyc |date=27 August 2018 |access-date=25 April 2020 |archive-date=21 February 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200221081558/http://www.graypanthersnyc.org/about_us/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>
[[Youth Liberation of Ann Arbor]] was an organization based in [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]]. It existed from 1970 to 1979, and is often cited in more recent academic literature as one of the leading forerunners of several [[youth movement]]s in the United States, including the [[youth rights movement]], [[youth voice|youth voice movement]], and the [[youth-led media|youth media movement]].
[[Three O'Clock Lobby]] formed in 1976 to promote [[youth participation]] throughout traditionally ageist government structures in Michigan.
Old Lesbians Organizing for Change was founded in 1987; the mission of the organization is to "eliminate the oppression of ageism and to stand in solidarity against all oppressions" through "[the] cooperative community of Old Lesbian feminist activists from many backgrounds working for justice and the well-being of all old lesbians."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/c8z89fjx/|title=Finding Aid for the Old Lesbians Organizing for Change records 1986–1992 LSC.2203|website=oac.cdlib.org}}</ref> Their initial meeting was inspired by the publication of the book ''Look Me in the Eye: Old Women, Aging and Ageism'' by [[Barbara Macdonald]] and Cynthia Rich in 1983.<ref name="ref2">{{cite web | url=http://asteria.fivecolleges.edu/findaids/sophiasmith/mnsss547_bioghist.html | title=Old Lesbians Organizing for Change Records | access-date=27 March 2015 | archive-date=11 September 2015 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150911172316/http://asteria.fivecolleges.edu/findaids/sophiasmith/mnsss547_bioghist.html | url-status=dead }}</ref>
Americans for a Society Free from Age Restrictions formed in 1996 to advance the civil and human rights of young people through eliminating ageist laws targeted against young people, and to help youth counter ageism in America.<ref>{{cite web|work=ASFAR |year=2006 |url=http://www.asfar.org/articles.php |title=Americans for a Society Free from Age Restrictions Articles of Incorporation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070609192032/http://www.asfar.org/articles.php |archive-date=9 June 2007}}</ref>
[[Peacefire]] is a [[United States|U.S.]]-based [[website]], with a registered address in [[Bellevue, Washington]], dedicated to "preserving [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] rights for [[Internet]] users, particularly those younger than 18". It was founded in August 1996 by [[Bennett Haselton]], who still runs it. The site's motto is, "You'll understand when you're younger."
[[File:NYRA Berkeley voting age protest.jpg|thumb|[[National Youth Rights Association]] members protesting the [[Voting age#United States|voting age]] in [[Berkeley, California]] (2004)]] The [[National Youth Rights Association]] started in 1998 to promote awareness of the legal and human rights of young people in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|work=National Youth Rights Association|year=2001|url=http://www.youthrights.org/docs/nyraarticlesofinc.pdf|title=National Youth Rights Association Articles of Incorporation (Partial)|access-date=18 May 2007|archive-date=25 February 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225142005/http://www.youthrights.org/docs/nyraarticlesofinc.pdf|url-status=dead}}</ref>
The [[Freechild Project]] was formed in 2001 in the United States to identify, unify and promote diverse opportunities for youth engagement in social change by fighting ageism.
The [[Global Youth Action Network]] (GYAN) is an international network of youth [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]]s spanning 180 countries, and headquartered in New York, near the United Nations. GYAN is a youth-led not for profit organization (registered in 2001, New York [USA], under section 501[c]3) that incubates global partnerships and increases youth participation in decision-making. GYAN has registered chapters in Brazil, Colombia, France, Ghana, Mexico, and South Africa, with teams working out of an additional eight countries.
In 2002 [[The Freechild Project]] created an information and training initiative to provide resources to youth organizations and schools focused on youth rights.<ref>(n.d.) [http://www.freechild.org/SNAYR/index.htm Survey of North American Youth Rights] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070206100316/http://www.freechild.org/SNAYR/index.htm |date=6 February 2007 }} The Freechild Project website.</ref>
[[Votes at 16]], founded in 2003, is a campaign in the [[United Kingdom]] which argues in favour of the reduction of the [[voting age]] to 16 for all public elections. The campaign espouses several principles in favour of lowering the voting age.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://votesat16.org.uk/|title=Votes at Sixteen Campaign|publisher=Votes at 16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030606185814/http://www.votesat16.org.uk/|url-status=usurped|archive-date=June 6, 2003}}</ref>
Director [[Paul Weitz (filmmaker)|Paul Weitz]] reported he wrote the 2004 film, ''[[In Good Company (2004 film)|In Good Company]]'', to reveal how ageism affects youth and adults.<ref>Hellerman, A. (2005) [http://www.wgaeast.org/features/2005/03/18/paul_weitz/index.html Working Solo in Good Company]{{Dead link|date=May 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Writers Guild of America, East website.</ref>
In 2006 Lydia Giménez-Llort, an assistant professor of Psychiatry and researcher at the [[Autonomous University of Barcelona]] coined the term "Snow White Syndrome" at the "Congrés de la Gent Gran de Cerdanyola del Vallès" (Congress of the Elderly of Cerdanyola del Vallès, Barcelona, Spain) as a metaphor to define ageism in an easier and more friendly way while developing a constructive spirit against it. The metaphor is based on both the auto-ageism and adultocracy exhibited by the [[Queen (Snow White)|evil queen]] of the [[Snow White]] fairy tale as well as the social ageism symbolized by the mirror.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saberenvejecer.es/saberhacer_30.html|language=es|title=Envellir bé · Successful Ageing · Saber Envejecer website – Know-how.|access-date=13 May 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090425094931/http://www.saberenvejecer.es/saberhacer_30.html|archive-date=25 April 2009|url-status=dead}}</ref>
Since 2008 "The Intergenerational Study" by Lydia Giménez-Llort and Paula Ramírez-Boix from the [[Autonomous University of Barcelona]] aims to find the basis of the link between grandparents and grandsons (positive family relationships) that can minimize the ageism towards the elderly. Students of several Spanish universities have enrolled in this study which soon will be also performed in the US, Nigeria, Barbados, Argentina, and Mexico. The preliminary results reveal that "The Intergenerational study questionnaire" induces young people to do a reflexive and autocritic analysis of their intergenerational relationships in contrast to those shown towards other unrelated old people which results very positive to challenge ageism. A cortometraje about "The International Study" has been directed and produced by Tomás Sunyer from [[Los Angeles City College]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saberenvejecer.es/investigar_25.html|language=es|title=Envellir bé : Successful Ageing · Saber envejecer website – Research.|access-date=13 May 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090423185650/http://www.saberenvejecer.es/investigar_25.html|archive-date=23 April 2009|url-status=dead}}</ref>
[[International Youth Rights]] (IYR), (Chinese: 国际青年权利会, Korean: 국제청소년권리협회) is a non-profit, non-political, international organization, founded in 2009 to advance the rights of youth. Its motto is "A united force of the youth, by the youth, for the youth and beyond."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://international-youth-rights.html/|title=International Youth Rights|website=international-youth-rights.html|language=en|access-date=15 July 2019}}</ref>
Queer activists glitter bombed Dan Savage on January 21, 2012, on the way into his "[[It Gets Better]]" show at the Vogue Theatre in Vancouver. His response was "Oh no! Not again!" The group said the bombing was in response to "ableism, ageism, classism, misogyny, racism, rape-apologism, [[serophobia]], sizism, transphobia and, oh yeah, [[Savage Love|that column]]".<ref>{{cite web |last=Oommen |first=Isaac |url=http://vancouver.mediacoop.ca/photo/dan-savage-glitterbombed/9681 |title=Dan Savage Glitterbombed |publisher=Vancouver Media Co-op |date=January 21, 2012 |access-date=January 26, 2012 |archive-date=May 11, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511055859/http://vancouver.mediacoop.ca/photo/dan-savage-glitterbombed/9681 |url-status=live }}</ref>
Chilean director [[Sebastian Lelio]] created a U.S. version of his acclaimed 2013 film ''[[Gloria (2013 film)|Gloria]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2017/11/will-a-us-adaptation-ruin-sebastian-lelios-gloria/543951/|title=Will a U.S. Adaptation Ruin Sebastian Lelio's Gloria?|last=Abbady|first=Tal|date=26 November 2017|website=The Atlantic|access-date=28 November 2017|archive-date=1 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201032323/https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2017/11/will-a-us-adaptation-ruin-sebastian-lelios-gloria/543951/|url-status=live}}</ref> The original film challenges the notion that as women age they become culturally "invisible";<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Isopahkala-Bouret|first=Ulpukka|date=2017|title="It's a great benefit to have gray hair!": The intersection of gender, aging, and visibility in midlife professional women's narratives|journal=Journal of Women & Aging|volume=29|issue=3|pages=267–277|doi=10.1080/08952841.2016.1142773|pmid=27629496|s2cid=33967941}}</ref> they may continue to be powerful, desirable, and sexually active. In the 2018 English [[remake]], titled ''[[Gloria Bell]]'', actress [[Julianne Moore]] portrayed the lead character.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cannes-julianne-moore-star-imagining-sebastian-lelios-gloria-1002948|title=Cannes: Julianne Moore to Star in Re-Imagining of Sebastian Lelio's 'Gloria'|last=Ford|first=Rebecca|date=12 May 2017|website=Hollywood Reporter|access-date=28 November 2017|archive-date=27 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171127003900/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cannes-julianne-moore-star-imagining-sebastian-lelios-gloria-1002948|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Dargis |first1=Manohla |title='Gloria Bell' Review: Love Is in the Air for a Transcendent Julianne Moore |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/07/movies/gloria-bell-review.html |access-date=29 July 2019 |work=The New York Times |date=7 March 2019}}</ref>
[[Choose Responsibility]] and their successor organization, the [[Amethyst Initiative]], founded by [[John McCardell, Jr.]], exist to promote the discussion of the drinking age, specifically. Choose Responsibility focuses on promoting a legal drinking age of 18, but includes provisions such as education and licensing. The Amethyst Initiative, a collaboration of college presidents and other educators, focuses on discussion and examination of the drinking age, with specific attention paid to the culture of alcohol as it exists on college campuses and the negative impact of the drinking age on alcohol education and responsible drinking.
The [http://europa.eu/youth/_en European Youth Portal] is the starting place for the European Union's youth policy, with [[Erasmus+]] as one of its key initiatives.
The [http://www.youthforum.org European Youth Forum] (YFJ, from Youth Forum Jeunesse) is the platform of the National Youth Council and International Non-Governmental Youth Organisations in Europe. It strives for youth rights in International Institutions such as the European Union, the Council of Europe and the United Nations. The European Youth Forum works in the fields of youth policy and youth work development. It focuses its work on European youth policy matters, whilst through engagement on the global level it is enhancing the capacities of its members and promoting global interdependence. In its daily work the European Youth Forum represents the views and opinions of youth organisations in all relevant policy areas and promotes the cross-sectoral nature of youth policy towards a variety of institutional actors. The principles of equality and sustainable development are mainstreamed in the work of the European Youth Forum. Other International youth rights organizations include [[Article 12 in Scotland]] and K.R.A.T.Z.A. in Germany.
[[Young India Foundation]] (YIF) is a youth-led youth rights organization in India, based in Gurgaon with regional chapters across India. Its aim is to make voices of youth be heard across India and seek representation for the 60% of India's demographic that is below the age of 25.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://youngindiafoundation.org|title=Home|website=Young India Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref> YIF is also the organization behind the age of candidacy campaign to bring down the age when a Member of Legislative Assembly or Member of Parliament can contest.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ageofcandidacy.in/|title=Age of Candidacy|website=ageofcandidacy.in|language=en|access-date=2018-07-17|archive-date=2018-07-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180718030912/https://ageofcandidacy.in/|url-status=dead}}</ref>
===Accusations of ageism=== In a 2005 interview, actor [[Pierce Brosnan]] cited ageism as one of the contributing factors as to why he was not asked to continue his role as [[James Bond]] in the Bond film ''[[Casino Royale (2006 film)|Casino Royale]]'', released in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|last = Cox|first = John|date = 5 November 2005|url = http://commanderbond.net/article/2994|title = Brosnan Bares All For Playboy|website = CommanderBond.net|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060702020428/http://commanderbond.net/article/2994|archive-date = 2 July 2006|access-date = 15 April 2019|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
Also, successful singer and actress [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] spoke out in her 50s about ageism and her fight to defy the norms of society.<ref>{{cite web|date = 18 June 2008|url = http://www.carefair.com/html/Madonna_Not_Giving_In_to_Ageism_5301.html|title = Madonna not giving in to Ageism|publisher = Care Fair|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081013071815/http://www.carefair.com/html/Madonna_Not_Giving_In_to_Ageism_5301.html|archive-date = 13 October 2008|access-date = 17 January 2009|df = dmy-all}}</ref> In 2015, [[Radio 1 Madonna controversy|BBC Radio 1 were accused of ageism]] after the station did not add her new single to their playlist. Similarly, ''[[Sex and the City]]'' star [[Kim Cattrall]] has also raised the issue of ageism.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=382 Kim Cattrall's red carpet rant: "down with Ageism and age discrimination"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240816172247/http://www.agediscrimination.info/news |date=16 August 2024 }}. Agediscrimination.info (5 April 2011). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
A 2007 [[Pew Research Center]] study found that a majority of American voters would be less likely to vote for a President past a given age,{{which|date=November 2017}} with 45% saying that age would not matter.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
[[Margaret Morganroth Gullette]]'s 2017 book, ''Ending Ageism or How Not to Shoot Old People'', provides multiple examples to illustrate the pervasiveness of ageism and delivers a call to action.<ref>{{Cite web |url = https://www.wbur.org/artery/2017/08/15/ending-ageism |title = Who Are You Calling Old? Brandeis Scholar Argues For An End To Ageism |author = Erin Trahan |date = 15 August 2017 |publisher = The ARTery |access-date = 29 October 2019 |archive-date = 29 October 2019 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20191029231217/https://www.wbur.org/artery/2017/08/15/ending-ageism |url-status = live }}</ref>
